gpaanjalousier

hans

maaskee
kun
beklage
sig
over
at
enkelte
godsejere
foi
lange
for
hoi
betaling
fur
fæstesteder
ja
det
er
neppe
anbefaleligt
men
det
kan
dog
ei
gaae
længere
end
der
er
liebhavere
til
stederne
men
saa
kunde
hr
—
g
med
mere
foie
beklage
sig
over
bøndernes
ledere
som
ved
deres
agitation
have
forhindret
en
stor
masse
af
bønder
i
at
kjøbe
deres
steder
for
og
j
del
af
den
sum
de
nu
maae
give
ved
at
foregøgle
dem
en
fæsleafløsningslovs
gyldne
tider
gid
disse
ærlige
folk
maae
see
deri
en
advarsel
for
fremtiden
hr
—
g
behøver
ei
at
frygte
for
at
en
dygtig
og
arbejdsom
bondestand
skulde
fortrænges
ira
eiendommene
ingen
stand
kan
bringe
det
ud
af
jorden
som
den
der
hver
dag
arbeid
r
med
og
bestandig
kan
give
sine
arbejdere
et
godt
exempel
naar
derfor
gejstligheden
og
skolelærerne
ville
sørge
for
at
børnene
lære
noget
godt
i
de
meget
kostbare
skoler
naar
børnene
opdrages
i
tugt
og
arbejdsomhed
naar
de
siden
søge
udmærkelse
ved
flid
arbejdsomhed
og
dygtighed
og
ei
i
dovenskab
overdaadighed
og
luxus
saa
vil
bonden
bedre
end
nogen
anden
være
i
stand
til
at
sørge
for
sine
børn
og
endda
kunne
kjøbe
eiendom
til
dem
jeg
maa
henvise
til
fy
en
og
langeland
hvor
eiendom
kjøbes
for
liøi
betaling
men
hvor
culturen
er
en
saadan
at
der
bliver
endda
et
klækkeligt
overskud
har
jeg
kjedet
læserne
saa
beder
jeg
om
forladelse
dog
troer
jeg
at
skylde
mig
selv
at
anføre
de
grunde
som
afholde
mig
fra
at
slutte
mig
til
hr
—
g
for
hvem
jeg
forresten
nærer
megen
agtelse
a
valen
tin
er

saaat

»monileur«

«

cdnao

som

„fadrclandets

on»

a
romance
by
captain
mayne
ileid
chapter
i
xiv
—
a
lilliputian
forest
on
resuming
the
trail
i
moved
with
lighter
spirit
i
had
three
sources
of
gratulation
the
peril
of
the
flood
was
past
—
she
was
not
drowned
the
wolves
were
thrown
off
—
the
dangerous
rapid
had
deterred
them
on
the
other
side
their
footprints
were
no
longer
found
thirdly
the
steed
had
slackened
his
pace
after
climbing
the
bank
he
had
set
off
in
a
rapid
gait
hut
not
at
a
gallop
he
s
been
pacin
liyar
remarked
garey
as
soon
as
his
eyes
rested
upon
the
tracks
pacing
i
knew
what
was
meant
by
this
i
knew
that
gait
peculiar
to
the
prairie
horse
fast
but
smooth
as
the
amble
of
a
palfrey
his
rider
would
scarcely
perceive
the
gentle
movement
her
torture
would
be
less
perhaps
too
no
longer
frighted
by
the
fierce
pursuers
the
horse
would
come
to
a
stop
his
wearied
limbs
would
admonish
him
and
then
surely
he
could
not
have
gone
much
further
we
too
were
wearied
one
and
all
but
these
pleasing
conjectures
beguiled
us
from
thinking
of
our
toil
and
we
advanced
more
cheerfully
along
the
trail
alas
it
was
my
fate
to
be
the
victim
of
alternate
hopes
and
fears
my
new
sprung
joy
was
short
lived
and
fast
fleeted
away
we
had
gone
but
a
few
hundred
paces
from
the
river
when
we
encountered
an
obstacle
that
proved
not
only
a
serious
barrier
to
our
progress
but
almost
brought
our
tracking
to
a
termination
this
obstacle
was
a
forest
of
oaks
not
giant
oaks
as
these
famed
trees
are
usually
designated
but
the
very
reverse
—
a
forest
of
dwarj
oaks
quercus
nana
far
as
the
eye
could
reach
extended
this
singular
wood
in
which
no
tree
rose
above
thirty
inches
in
height
yet
was
it
no
thicket
—
no
undcr
growth
of
shrubs
—
but
a
true
forest
of
oaks
each
tree
having
its
separate
stem
its
boughs
its
lobed

and
its

of
brown
acorns
shin
oak
cried
the
trappers
as
we
entered
the
verge
of
this
miniature
forest
wagli
exclaimed
l
ubc
in
a
tone
of
impatience
hyur
s
bother
ee
may
all
get
out
o
yur
saddles
an
rest
yur
critters
we
11
hev
to
crawl
byur
and
so
it
resulted
for
long
weary
hours
we
followed
the
trail
going
not
faster
than
we
could
have
crawled
upon
our
hands
and
knees
the
tracks
of
the
steed
were
plain
enough
and
in
daylight
could
have
been
easily
followed
but
the
little
oaks
grew
close
and
regular
as
if
planted
by
the
hand
of
man
and
through
their
thick
foliage
the
moonlight
scarcely
penetrated
their
boughs
almost
touched
each
other
so
that
the
whole
surface
lay
in
dark
shadow
rendering
it
1
most
impossible
tomakeout
the
hoof
prints
here
and
there
a
broken

or
a
bunch
of
tossed
leaves
—
their
under
sides
shining

in
the

enabled

to
advance
at
a
quicker

but
as
the
horse
had
passed
gently
over
the
ground
these
signs
were
few
and
iur
between
for
long

hours
we
toiled
through
the
shin
oak
forest
our
heads
far
overtopping
its
tallest
trees
we
might
have
fancied
that
we
were
threading
our
way
through
some
extended

the
trail
led
directly
across
its
central
part
and
ere
we
had
reached
its
furthest
verge
the
moon
s
rays
were
mingling
with
the
purple
light
of
morning
soon
after
the
forest
opened
tho
little
dwarfs
grew
further
a
part
—
here
scattered
thinly
over
the
ground
there
disposed
in
clumps
or
miniature
groves
—
until
at
length
the
sward
of
the
prairie
predominated
the
trouble
of
the
tracker
was
at
an
end
the
welcome
light
of
the
sun
was
thrown
upon
the
trail
so
that
they
could
lift
it
as
fast
as
we
could
ride
and
no
longer
hindered
by
brake
or
bush
we
advanced
at
a
rapid
rate
across
the
prairie
over
this
ground
the
steed
had
also
passed
rapidly
he
had
continued
to
pace
for
some
distance
after
emerging
from
the
shin
oak
forest
but
all
at
once
as
we
could
tell
by
his
tracks
he
had
bounded
off
again
and
resumed
his
head

gallop

Æm—wjx

—
under
10de
juli
er
hs
exe

ad

og

o

forventningsfuld
tvivl
om
hvorvidt
der
her
handles
om
hans
egen
private
møllesag
eller
ikke
thi
det
er
det
sørgelige
ved
det
hele
forhold
enhver
by
ja
næsten
ethvert
sogn
har
sin

om

enhver

til
al
have
og
haandhævc
sin

anskuelse

op

de
store

spørgsmaal
der

enhver

og
er

endnu
ikke

det
cardinalpunkt
hvorom

sig

er

hertil
i
ethvert

ikke

er

om
en

om

og

med

at

—

lonert
leonhartus
i
busum
og
hr
reimer
af
seecken
slægten
i
hensted
holdt
offentlig
med
dem
men
saasnart
gerhard
den
trerie
havde
besteget
ten
crkebifloppelige
stol
reiste
der
sig
en
be
vægelse
imod
dem
sandhedens
fjender
gjorte
begyndelsen
med
at
for
folge
henricus
grove
han
tom
i
aaret
1451
til
lunden
for
at
be
soge
sine

og
vise
rem
veien
til
salighed
munkene
ophiv
sete
navnlig
rannerne
og
schwinerne
til
at
gribe
ham
og
enten
tvinge
ham
til
at
gjenkalde
eller
dræbe
ham
man

deres
onde
raad
men
da
man
ikke
stra
kunde
bringe
bam
til
at
gjenkalde
anviste
man

et
fængsel
for
at

envnu

faae

til
at
besinde
sig
og
beslutte
sig

men
han

forventede

ind
i

at

til

for

at
han
dog
vilde

ham
fra
den

saa
forstotket
men
hemmeligt
havde
rannerne
og

allerede
ophidset
pobelcn
til
at
ombringe
ham
dersom

vilde

til

og

da
han

i

tydeligt

at

—

i

for

for

vedkommende
ved
hin

var
—
det
er
sandt
—

i
formel

svækket
men
i
realiteten
vare

under

i

for

og

et

og

af

og
